ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Berkeley Farms - Hayward is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all employees and the surrounding communities. Berkeley Farms - Hayward administers the safety and environmental policies and programs.  These programs include but are not limited to forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.



The Berkeley Farms - Hayward facility has independently coordinated emergency response efforts with the local Fire Department.  In the case of an ammonia emergency, it is the policy of Berkeley Farms - Hayward to evacuate

the employees and to allow the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Berkeley Farms - Hayward facility is located at 25500 Clawiter Road in Hayward, California, which is approximately 0.2 miles north of Highway 92 and 1.4 miles west of Interstate 880. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of commercial and residential areas.  



In order to conduct operations, the facility currently uses a maximum of 26,500 pounds of ammonia in its ammonia refrigeration system. The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) to provide refrigeration for cold storage and manufacturing of dairy products.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Berkeley Farms - Hayward ammonia system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. 



The PSM / RMP / CalARP program ensures that all security and safety procedures are addressed.  Staff is trained in operation, maintenance and emergency procedures related to the operation of the ammonia system.  All pressure vessels in the ammonia system are equipped with relief valves that vent to the atmosphere at a certain pressure set point. A preventative maintenance program assures that equipment is maintained and serviced on a regular schedule and that worn, aging, or defective components are replaced as required to maintain equipment in good operating condition.  Controls and safety devices are inspected regularly to ensure proper operation.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"An unanticipated emission of a regulated substance or other extremely hazardous substance into the amb

ient air from a stationary source."



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted during the Process Hazard Analysis study on June 6, 2019, there have been no releases of ammonia that meet this criteria in the past five years (June 2014 - June 2019). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Berkeley Farms - Hayward is a non-responding facility and has an emergency action plan (EAP) in effect. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1. To save lives.

2. To minimize and avoid injuries.

3. To protect the environment.

4. To minimize property damage.



The operator of the facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM / RMP / CalARP regulations.



In the event of an ammonia emergency, the operator of the Berkeley Farms - Hayward facility plans to evacuate all employees in the facility and alert the local emergency responders (fire department). The operator of the facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study, conducted on June 6, 2019, including a Hazard and Oper

ability (HAZOP) study and a facility inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Berkeley Farms - Hayward facility. Berkeley Farms - Hayward's safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

 

EPA RMP CDX SUBMISSION NOTES



Item numbers 7.11.a and 7.11.b have been intentionally left blank.  These items (Incident Investigation, etc.) have been developed for Berkeley Farms - Hayward and will be implemented when required.  In addition, the Emergency Action Plan outlines evacuation routes, notification procedures, and reporting procedures in the event of an emergency, which could include fire, ammonia release, blackout, and earthquake.
